title: My cousin died. I am one of several next-of-kin, but the only one willing to help contact creditors, etc. I can't afford a
question: lawyer. Cousin was in debt, so no assets to speak of. The house will go into foreclosure. I am only helping as a courtesy, I do not want any legal or financial liability. What happens now?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Foreclosure,Executor of will,Probate,Probate court
answers:
You have no legal liability for the debts of your cousin and no liability to assist his creditors. I would suggest you save your efforts if the estate is bankrupt there is nothing you can do to help and will be wasting your time and efforts only to potentially benefit creditors.

you don't take on any legal or financial liability for helping. if the estate does not have enough money (in cash or assets) to cover its bills then the estate goes through an insolvent probate process. you can act as the executor of the estate or the court can appoint someone. your first steps would include getting a copy of the death certificate and contact the probate court.
